docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: Sandal is a lightweight portable container environment controller, designed and work with Linux systems.

docs.title: Goal of This Project
docs.text:
Sandal creates intermediate layer between host operating system and containers without requiring dedicated memory allocation like as virtual machines.

  • This project supports provision container from directories, immutable image files (IMG, Squash FS) so you can execute the container directly from the file, and easy to distribute and configure it with portable media.

  • Portable container images gives ability to provision containers from outside the system host storage system such as SD cards, That enables to access and manage from outside (macOS, Windows) the host operating system when the system is offline.

  • Easy deployment, enables remote deployment without requiring any software or deep experience at field side.

  • Additionally, these features create easy to manage embedded-Linux work environments or development surface without requiring to build own distribution (Yocto, Buildroot) from scratch for each change.

docs.title: Run
docs.text:
This sub command provisiones a new container to the system.

Example usage
sandal run -lw / -tmp 10 --rm --  bash

docs.title: Flags
docs.text: Flag Type Description bool by default it is set to false, in case of presence, it will be true. string only accepts single string value. value similar to string but multiple presences are accepted

docs.title: -cap-add value
docs.text: add capabilities to the container (multiple values allowed) See Linux Capabilities for available capabilities. Example: -cap-add NET_BIND_SERVICE -cap-add SYS_ADMIN By default, containers start with a restricted set of capabilities. This flag adds additional capabilities when needed.

docs.title: -cap-drop value
docs.text: drop capabilities from the container (multiple values allowed) Remove specific capabilities even in privileged mode. Example: -cap-drop SYS_ADMIN -cap-drop NET_ADMIN This provides an additional layer of security by explicitly removing potentially dangerous capabilities.

docs.title: --cpu string
docs.text: limit the number of CPUs available to the container Specify the maximum number of CPUs the container can use as a decimal value. Uses cgroup v2 cpu controller to enforce CPU throttling. Example: --cpu 0.5 (half a CPU), --cpu 2 (two CPUs) The value is rounded up to the nearest integer for display in /proc/cpuinfo. Note: Requires cgroup v2 with cpu controller available. If unavailable, a warning is logged but the container continues to run.

docs.title: -chdir string
docs.text: container changes will saved this directory (default "/var/lib/sandal/changedir/new-york")

docs.title: -d bool
docs.text: run container in background

docs.title: -devtmpfs string
docs.text: mount point of devtmpfs example: -devtmpfs /mnt/devtmpfs more info unix.stackexchange.com

docs.title: -dir string
docs.text: working directory Default it is set to root folder /

docs.title: -env-all bool
docs.text: send all enviroment variables to container Environment variables which currently you are seing at env command.

docs.title: -env-pass value
docs.text: pass only requested enviroment variables to container For example you are set variable with export FOO=BAR, and -env-pass FOO will read variable from existing environment and passes to container. It does not accepts -env-pass FOO=BAR for security purposes

docs.title: -help bool
docs.text: show this help message

docs.title: -hosts string
docs.text: cp (copy), cp-n (copy if not exist), image(use image) (default "cp") Allocation configuration of /etc/hosts file.

docs.title: -lw value
docs.text:
Lower directory of the root file system Lower directories are attach folders or images to container to access but changes are saved under -chdir. This flag can usable multiple times to attach multiple images and directories to container. More

Example Commands

# Single Lower Directory
sandal run -lw /my/dir/lw1 -- bash
# Multiple Lower Directories
sandal run -lw /my/dir/lw1 -lw /my/dir/lw2 -lw /my/dir/lw3 -- bash
# SquashFS # (1)
sandal run -lw /my/img/debian.sqfs -lw /my/image/config.sqfs -- bash
# Mounting .img file # (2)
sandal run -tmp 1000 -lw /my/img/2024-11-19-raspios-bookworm-arm64-lite.img:part=2 \
-lw /my/image/config.sqfs --rm -- bash
  1. You can create SquashFS files with sandal convert.
  2. Image files consist of multiple partition, you have to specificly define partition information in commandline. You can find image details with sandal image info file.img

Read file operation

graph LR
M1([MyApp]) --Access--> O1[OverlayFs]
O1 -- Return File --> M1

O1[OverlayFs] --> E4
E4{Exist at chdir ?} -- Yes | Read from --> C1[(ChangeDir)]
E4 -- No | TRY --> E3

E3{Exist at lw3 ?} -- Yes | Read from --> LW3[(lower3)] 
E3 -- No | TRY --> E2

E2{Exist at lw2 ?} -- Yes | Read from --> LW2[(lower2)] 
E2 -- No | TRY --> E1

E1{Exist at lw3 ?} -- Yes | Read from --> LW1[(lower1)]
E1 -- No | File Not Found --> O1

Write file operation

graph LR
M1([MyApp]) --Write--> O1[OverlayFs]

O1[OverlayFs] --> C1[(ChangeDir)]

docs.title: --memory string
docs.text:
limit the memory available to the container Specify the maximum amount of memory the container can use. Supports human-readable units: K, M, G, T (1000-based) or Ki, Mi, Gi, Ti (1024-based). Uses cgroup v2 memory controller to enforce memory limits (triggers OOM killer if exceeded). Custom /proc/meminfo is generated to show the limited memory inside the container.

Example usage: 

sandal run --memory 512M -lw / -- bash    # 512 megabytes
sandal run --memory 1G -lw / -- bash      # 1 gigabyte
sandal run --memory 1Gi -lw / -- bash     # 1 gibibyte (1024-based)
sandal run --memory 134217728 -lw / -- bash  # 128MB in bytes

Note: Requires cgroup v2 with memory controller available. If unavailable, a warning is logged and only /proc/meminfo is customized (without kernel enforcement).

docs.title: -name string
docs.text: name of the container (default "new-york")

docs.title: -net value
docs.text:
container network interface configuration 
# Allocate custom interface only
sandal run -lw / -net "ip=172.19.0.3/24=fd34:0135:0127::9/64" -- bash
# Allocate default and custom interface with different bridge
sandal run -lw / -net "" -net "ip=172.19.0.3/24=fd34:0135:0127::9/64;master=br0" -- bash
# Custom interface naming
sandal run -lw / -net "" -net "name=pppoe;master=layer2" -- bash
# Custom mtu or ethernet set
sandal run -lw / -net "" -net "ether="aa:ee:81:f4:c0:d3";mtu=1480" -- bash

docs.title: -ns-cgroup string
docs.text: cgroup namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-ipc string
docs.text: ipc namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-mnt string
docs.text: mnt namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-net string
docs.text: net namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-ns string
docs.text: ns namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-pid string
docs.text: pid namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-time string
docs.text: time namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-user string
docs.text: user namespace or host

docs.title: -ns-uts string
docs.text: uts namespace or host

docs.title: -rci value
docs.text:
run command before init 
sandal run -rm -lw / -rci="ifconfig eth0" -- echo hello

docs.title: -rcp value
docs.text:
run command before pivoting. 
sandal run -rm -lw / -rci="ifconfig eth0" -- echo hello

docs.title: -privileged bool
docs.text: give extended privileges to the container When enabled, the container runs with all Linux capabilities (except those explicitly dropped with -cap-drop). ⚠️ Warning: This significantly increases security risks. Use only when absolutely necessary. Equivalent to Docker's --privileged flag. The container will have access to host devices and can perform system-level operations.

docs.title: -rdir string
docs.text: root directory of operating system for container init process (default "/")

docs.title: -resolv string
docs.text: cp (copy), cp-n (copy if not exist), image (use image), 1.1.1.1;2606:4700:4700::1111 (provide nameservers) (default "cp")

docs.title: -rm bool
docs.text: remove container files on exit

docs.title: -ro bool
docs.text: read only rootfs

docs.title: -startup
docs.text: run container at startup by sandal daemon

docs.title: -tmp uint
docs.text:
allocate changes at memory instead of disk. Unit is in MB, when set to 0 (default) which means it's disabled. Benefical for:
  • Provisioning ephemeral environments
  • Able to execute sandal under sandal or docker with tmpfs to prevent overlayFs in overlayFs limitations
  • Reduce disk calls for writing
  • Work with not supported file systems such as fat32, exfat

docs.title: -user string
docs.text:
Start container as custom user or user:group configuration. 
# chroot to given path
sandal run -rm --lw / -user dnsmasq -- id
uid=100(dnsmasq) gid=101(dnsmasq)
sandal run -rm --lw / -user dnsmasq:wheel -- id
uid=100(dnsmasq) gid=10(wheel)
sandal run -rm --lw / -user 10:nogroup -- id
uid=10(uucp) gid=65533(nogroup)
sandal run -rm --lw / -user 10 -- id
uid=10(uucp) gid=10(wheel)
sandal run -rm --lw / -user adm:10 -- id
uid=3(adm) gid=10(wheel)

docs.title: -v value
docs.text:
volume mount point 
# chroot to given path
sandal run -rm -v /mnt/disk1:/ -- bash
#  attach file,attach path to custom path, attach path, and  to the container.
sandal run -rm -v /etc/nftables.conf \
  -v /run/dbus \
  -v /etc/homeas/config:/config  -- bash

docs.title: Clear
docs.text:
Clear removes stale containers which they have -rm flag during execution.

sandal clear

To clear all containers which they are not in running state you can execute clear with -all argument

sandal clear -all

Usage of exec:
  -all
        delete all containers which they are not in running state
  -help
        show this help message

docs.title: Cmd
docs.text:
Print sandal run ... command of particular container or all containers.

sandal cmd new-york
    sandal run -name new-york -tmp 10 -lw /nvme1/sandal/images/debian.sq -- bash

sandal cmd -all
    sandal run -name new-york -tmp 10 -lw /nvme1/sandal/images/debian.sq -- bash
    sandal run -name istanbul -ns-net host -lw / -- nginx
    sandal run -lw / -- ping localhost
    ...

docs.title: Daemon
docs.text:
You can start your containers with run command but for following requirements suggested to use daemon service instead of standalone.

  • Automatically starting containers at the boot
  • Rerun container when process is exits
  • Work with read-only disk system and keep current state at memory
  • Reduce read and write calls to system disk for updating or getting state information

docs.title: Registering the Service
docs.text:
Installation of daemon supports Systemd and Open RC init systems.

sandal daemon -install

You can start service with your system init and service controller.

managing
sh title="service control" annote
# service sandal [start|stop|restart]
service sandal start # (1)!
  1. Output of service command varies between Systemd and OpenRC but it does not have impact.

docs.title: Service Start
docs.text: Provisiones containers which they have a -d and --startup arguments placed while creating with sandal run command.

docs.title: Service Stop
docs.text:
Daemon has signal proxy to transfer received following signals to containers.

  • SIGINT (2)
  • SIGQUIT (3)
  • SIGTERM (15)

If container does not gracefully shut down in 30 second when the signal is recived by contianer, daemon itself will send SIGKILL (9) to the container for ending the process.

docs.title: Container Death
docs.text: Health check function checks existence of container Process ID (PID), if not, it re-provisions container with same run arguments.

docs.title: File Events at Sandal State Directory
docs.text: In case of manual actions under Sandal state directly, system reads those actions and reloads files into daemon. Note: File Events only supported physically attached storage systems. Network attached storage (SMB, NFS) does capable to send those events.

docs.title: Exec
docs.text:
Execute a command under given container.

export MY_VAR="test_var"
sandal exec -env-pass MY_VAR new-york -- env
    PATH=/sbin:/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
    MY_VAR=test_var

docs.title: Custom Namespaces
docs.text: Sandal is flexiable to execute your custom process with in different namespace.

docs.title: Host
docs.text:
To keep nep process on default namespace while environment is in created container.

sandal exec --env-all --ns-net host test -- ifconfig

docs.title: Proccess ID (PID)
docs.text:
System is capable to provisioning new process from other processes namespaces.

sandal exec --env-all --ns-net pid:5321 test -- ifconfig

docs.title: File
docs.text:
Jump namespaces which is created from other tools is done by giving path of namespace endpoint.

ip netns create test
sandal exec --env-all --ns-net file:/var/run/netns/test test -- ifconfig

docs.title: Inspect
docs.text:
List configuration file of given container.

sandal inspect new-york

{
        "Name": "new-york",
        "Created": 1736884685,
        "HostPid": 222194,
        "ContPid": 222200,
        "TmpSize": 10,
        ....
}

docs.title: Kill
docs.text:
Stop or send custom signal to your container

sandal kill klipper

docs.title: -signal int
docs.text:
Define custom signal for kill request.

sandal kill -signal 3 homeasistant

docs.title: -timeout string
docs.text:
Kill commands wait to proccess complate and you can define time out for this command to give up.

sandal kill -signal 2 -timeout 10 homeasistant

docs.title: Ps
docs.text:
List your, containers with status informations.

sandal ps
NAME              LOWER                              COMMAND CREATED              STATUS PID
new-york ["/nvme1/sandal/images/debian.sq"] bash    2025-01-18T16:56:13Z          exit 0 280573
istanbul ["/"]                              bash    2024-09-21T14:29:51Z          exit 0 549032

docs.title: Rerun
docs.text:
Kill previos container and re exec with same arguments

sandal rerun new-york
Note

Sandal does not save any informations related to environment variable. If you are executing container with passenv or envall arguments, environment variables information is getting from executed shell environment. From different shell or session, if you forget to set those variables, your container will be miss those environment variables.

docs.title: Rm
docs.text:
Delete containers from system.

sandal rm new-york

docs.title: Stop
docs.text:
Stop or send custom signal to your container, system will not try to restart your container.

sandal stop klipper

docs.title: -signal int
docs.text:
Define custom signal for kill request.

sandal stop -signal 3 homeasistant

docs.title: -timeout string
docs.text:
Kill commands wait to proccess complate and you can define time out for this command to give up.

sandal stop -signal 2 -timeout 10 homeasistant

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This software is independent to work with variety Linux distribution, it is only requiring some Linux kernel capabilities which is supported by most of the ready-made distribution.

docs.title: From GitHub
docs.text:
System is single binary and for installation, you can directly download from GitHub releases.

Set your system architecture. For Raspberry Pi 4 and newer you can set arm64 for others, armv7 and first generation can use armv6.

Available Prebuild Binary Architectures 
ARCH=amd64  # 64 Bit regular system
ARCH=386    # Old x86 machines
ARCH=arm64  # 64 Bit Arm, Raspberry Pi 4, Raspberry PI 5
ARCH=armv7  # 32 Bit Arm, Raspberry Pi 3-4-5
ARCH=armv6  # Raspberry Pi 1 and other old SBCs

Download prebuild binary.

sudo wget https://github.com/ahmetozer/sandal/releases/latest/download/sandal-linux-${ARCH} -O /usr/bin/sandal

Set executable permission

sudo chmod +x /usr/bin/sandal

Test downloaded version.

sandal help

docs.title: From Source
docs.text:
If Golang is already installed, you can get and build at locally.

go install github.com/ahmetozer/sandal@latest
sandal help

docs.title: Starting at boot
docs.text:
System has own daemon to run your containers at startup. To achieve this, you need to register sandal daemon service to your init component.

Registration information are available at Daemon

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Each sub command will be configured by, flags and you can find details under /guide/commands/* pages. Project wide configurations are use environment variables for setting.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
You can list default, current and defined environement variable configuration with sandal help command.

sandal help
System variable information:
  Variable Name             Set by user                         Used as                             Default
  SANDAL_LIB_DIR            /tmp/sandal/lib                     /tmp/sandal/lib                     /var/lib/sandal
  SANDAL_RUN_DIR            /tmp/sandal/run                     /tmp/sandal/run                     /var/run/sandal
  SANDAL_IMAGE_DIR                                              /tmp/sandal/lib/image               /var/lib/sandal/image
  SANDAL_STATE_DIR                                              /tmp/sandal/lib/state               /var/lib/sandal/state
  SANDAL_CHANGE_DIR                                             /tmp/sandal/lib/changedir           /var/lib/sandal/changedir
  SANDAL_ROOTFSDIR                                              /tmp/sandal/run/rootfs              /var/run/sandal/rootfs
  SANDAL_IMMUTABLEIMAGEDIR                                      /tmp/sandal/run/immutable           /var/run/sandal/immutable
  SANDAL_HOST_NET           172.19.0.1/24;fd34:0135:0127::1/64  172.19.0.1/24;fd34:0135:0127::1/64  172.16.0.1/24;fd34:0135:0123::1/64
  SANDAL_SOCKET                                                 /tmp/sandal/run/sandal.sock         /var/run/sandal/sandal.sock
  SANDAL_LOG_LEVEL          debug                               debug                               info

docs.title: SANDAL_LIB_DIR
docs.text: This variable provides path for working directory for project which keeps the files.

docs.title: SANDAL_RUN_DIR
docs.text: Directory allocation for current runtime such as mountings. After system reboot, those directories can be deleted by your operating system and sandal will be re-allocate those paths.

docs.title: SANDAL_IMAGE_DIR
docs.text: Default path for images such as SquashFS or Disk images.

docs.title: SANDAL_STATE_DIR
docs.text: Your container execution configurations and states will save under given directory.

docs.title: SANDAL_CHANGE_DIR
docs.text: File and folder changes under container will save under this directory. This has no effect unless you have been set -chdir argument while starting up the container.

docs.title: SANDAL_ROOTFSDIR
docs.text: Root file system which is seen by container environment. It is combunation if lowerlayers, mounted valumes and changes which is made in container.

docs.title: SANDAL_IMMUTABLEIMAGEDIR
docs.text: Immutable images are require to be mounted to operating system for using at containers.

docs.title: SANDAL_HOST_NET
docs.text: Default host network configuration.

docs.title: SANDAL_SOCKET
docs.text: Socket location of the sandal state service.

docs.title: SANDAL_LOG_LEVEL
docs.text:
Sandal software supports leveled logging and by default runs as info mode. Supported levels are:

  • debug
  • info
  • warn
  • error
